case_vignette:
A 32-year-old Caucasian man presents to the physician because of the swelling and discomfort of the right testis for 3 weeks. There is no history of trauma, fever, or night sweats. He had surgery for an undescended right testis when he was 6 months old. There is no history of liver disease or hypogonadism. He has fathered 2 children. He takes no medications and denies any illicit drug use. The vital signs are within normal limits. Palpation of the scrotum reveals a firm nontender mass that cannot be separated from the right testis. Examination of the left testis shows no abnormalities. There is no supraclavicular or inguinal lymphadenopathy. Gynecomastia is present. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Ultrasound shows an enlarged right testicle with a hypoechoic mass replacing a large portion of the normal architecture. The left testis is normal. The laboratory test results are as follows:
HCG Elevated
AFP Elevated
LDH Normal
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been experiencing swelling and discomfort in my right testicle for the past 3 weeks.
Are there any associated symptoms such as fever, urinary changes, or pain?
No, I haven't had any fever, changes in urination, or pain.
Have you had any trauma or injury to the scrotal area recently?
No, I haven't had any trauma or injury to that area.
Have you noticed any lumps or changes in the size of your testicles?
Yes, there's a firm lump on my right testicle that I can't separate from it.
Do you have a personal or family history of testicular cancer or undescended testicles?
I had surgery for an undescended right testis when I was 6 months old.
Have you experienced any weight loss, fatigue, or lower back pain recently?
No, I haven't experienced weight loss, fatigue, or lower back pain.
Final Diagnosis: Testicular cancer, likely seminoma, given the history of undescended testis and presence of a firm lump.
